title: Southeast Asia's Political Risks, Tech Rout Puts Pressure on Markets
description: "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade" brings you everything you need to know to get ahead as the trading day begins in Asia. (Source: Bloomberg)

summary: The Asian Trade Council (SCO) has begun meeting with world leaders, including the Chinese President XI JinPing and Prime Minister MODI of India, to discuss reopening Ties between them. This comes after a U.S. court ruling on President Donald Trump's TARIFFS ILLEGA, leading to political uncertainty in both Thailand and Indonesia. This has led to the President to cancel a visit to China. Meanwhile, Asian markets are seeing increased volatility, with Japanese stock gaining 3/10 of 1%. The SCO is set to welcome over 20 world leaders. However, MODI will not be attending the SCO's meeting.
shortSummary: Political tensions and a tech Rout are pressuring Asian markets, with volatile markets and trade tensions highlighted by the U.S. TARIFFS ruling, impacting investor confidence and economic stability.
argos_summary: Asian markets remain cautious after a U.S. court declared Trump’s tariffs illegal, amid political unrest in Thailand and Indonesia that has pressured governments to curb perks and calm protests. The Shanghai Cooperation Organization summit saw China, India, Russia and other leaders discuss trade and security, while the U.S. continues to impose and potentially lift tariffs, creating uncertainty for global supply chains. Market reactions include modest gains in Nikkei and S&P futures, but volatility remains high as investors weigh the impact of trade policy, chip export restrictions, and geopolitical tensions on growth and inflation dynamics.
